categories.DESCRIPTION: Explores how sound travels, what causes sounds, and how we hear them. Helps children understand that sound is a physical phenomenon they can observe and experiment with in their environment.
categories.EXAMPLE_ACTIVITIES: Creating simple musical instruments from household items to explore pitch and volume; Using tuning forks in water to see sound waves; Feeling throat vibrations while humming different notes

categories.DESCRIPTION: Introduces basic mechanical devices that make work easier through hands-on exploration. Builds understanding of how everyday tools work and how forces can be redirected or amplified.
categories.EXAMPLE_ACTIVITIES: Building and testing ramps at different angles; Using pulleys to lift lightweight objects; Creating a lever system with a ruler and fulcrum

categories.DESCRIPTION: Investigates how light travels, interacts with objects, and creates shadows. Connects to daily observations of natural and artificial light while introducing basic concepts of reflection and opacity.
categories.EXAMPLE_ACTIVITIES: Shadow puppet theater with different light sources; Making rainbows with prisms; Testing which materials block or allow light to pass through

categories.DESCRIPTION: Explores magnetic forces and their effects on various materials. Introduces the concept of invisible forces while allowing for safe and engaging hands-on discovery.
categories.EXAMPLE_ACTIVITIES: Testing which household items are magnetic; Creating magnetic art with iron filings; Making a floating magnetic sculpture

categories.DESCRIPTION: Focuses specifically on how materials can change from one state to another through heating and cooling. Builds on children's experiences with everyday substances like water, chocolate, and butter.
categories.EXAMPLE_ACTIVITIES: Making popsicles and observing melting; Watching steam condense on a cool surface; Creating and melting crayon art

categories.DESCRIPTION: Investigates center of gravity, weight distribution, and what makes things stay upright or fall over. Connects to children's natural curiosity about building and stacking while introducing fundamental physics concepts.
categories.EXAMPLE_ACTIVITIES: Building and testing block towers of different shapes; Creating mobiles that balance; Exploring how to make spinning tops stay upright

skills.DESCRIPTION: Identify and differentiate between various environmental sounds (loud/soft, near/far, natural/artificial)
skills.CONNECTIONS: Language Arts (descriptive vocabulary), Social Studies (environmental awareness)

skills.DESCRIPTION: Recognize that sounds are created by vibrations through simple demonstrations (rubber bands, drums, voice box)
Demonstrate understanding that sound travels through different materials (air, water, solids) through experiments
Create and control sounds of different volumes and understand the concept of amplitude
Create and repeat simple sound patterns using classroom instruments or body percussion
Draw or chart different sounds heard in various locations and categorize them
Explore and understand how sounds can bounce back (basic echo concept) through experimentation
Create simple musical instruments using household materials to demonstrate sound production
skills.PREREQUISITES: Vibration Basics, Sound Travel, Volume Exploration

skills.DESCRIPTION: Recognize and name the six basic simple machines (lever, wheel and axle, pulley, inclined plane, wedge, and screw) in everyday objects
Demonstrate understanding that simple machines help us push and pull things more easily through hands-on experimentation
Identify and explain how simple machines are used in playground equipment (slides as inclined planes, seesaws as levers)
skills.PREREQUISITES: Machine Identification, Push and Pull Forces
skills.CONNECTIONS: Physical Education, Social Skills, Safety Awareness

skills.DESCRIPTION: Sort common tools and objects by the type of simple machine they represent (hammer as lever, screwdriver as wheel and axle)
Experiment with different inclined plane angles to observe how they affect the speed and effort needed to move objects
Create and test simple vehicles using wheels and axles to understand how they make movement easier
skills.PREREQUISITES: Machine Identification, Push and Pull Forces

skills.DESCRIPTION: Use simple levers to solve basic weight-lifting challenges, understanding the concept of effort and load
skills.PREREQUISITES: Push and Pull Forces, Playground Physics

skills.DESCRIPTION: Identify and explain how multiple simple machines work together in common objects (scissors use both levers and wedges)
Create basic drawings or models of new tools using simple machines to solve a given problem
skills.PREREQUISITES: Machine Identification, Tool Classification, Push and Pull Forces
